docs.lead_paragraph: Supplies of illegal heroin and cocaine have grown so plentiful in the New York City area that drug experts see a dissolving of the traditional lines between people who use the two drugs as well as between people who sell them. Heroin addiction, while still more prevalent among the poor, has recently risen among members of the white middle class, rehabilitation experts say. And cocaine appears to be contributing to the increase. A state study has found that some cocaine abusers have become addicted to heroin after experimenting with that drug to overcome the mental anxieties created by cocaine. At the same time, cocaine, once the exclusive preserve of wealthy drug users, has become a popular street drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: -year struggle, a bill exempting group homes for the mentally ill from local zoning ordinances emerged this year from the General Assembly. If the bill is signed into law by Governor O'Neill, zoning experts say, many towns will have to remove a number of zoning restrictions on the placement of group homes. In Windham, for example, where the zoning board is considering a proposal for such a facility, the law would mean ''a new way of looking at the issue'' of group homes, according to Hallie Krider, co-chairman of the board. For her part, Deborah Carr, a deputy commissioner of the State Department of Mental Health, said: ''We've worked very hard on this for four years now. One of our major priorities has been the development of these transitional facilities.''

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO months into her yearlong treatment with five drugs to control breast cancer, Judy and her partner won the mixed doubles tournament at their New York club. When the medication makes her tired and nauseous, she works at home instead of going to the office. A co-worker of Judy's who went through similar treatment hardly missed a day of work during the year of postoperative therapy; when fatigue overwhelmed her, she simply took a nap in the ladies' room. Rena Blumberg, a Cleveland broadcaster who described her experience with cancer chemotherapy in ''Headstrong'' (Crown, $12.95), coped by working extra hours when she felt well and staying home to rest when the treatments made her ill. This is not to say, of course, that she was spared from distressing and embarrassing times when side effects took her by surprise or temporarily seemed beyond tolerance, or that her generally sunny outlook completely protected her from depression, anxiety and irritability. She simply kept reminding herself of all she had to live for each time she faced another round of treatment.

docs.lead_paragraph: CHEMOTHERAPY, once the black sheep of cancer treatments, has become the leading weapon for increasing the number of patients who can be cured of cancer. At the same time, researchers are reducing the debilitating side effects that chemotherapy patients have typically had to endure. Furthermore, new drugs, and new methods of using old ones, hold out the promise that there will soon be significant improvements in fighting some of the most common cancer killers. ''When chemotherapy was developed in the 1950's, cancer survival statistics were pretty much static,'' observed Dr. Bruce Chabner, head of the National Cancer Institute's Division of Cancer Treatment. ''Surgery had gone as far as it could go in curing local disease, and the radiation therapy of the 60's and 70's only improved the cure of local and regional disease.''

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY of them lead lives of emptiness, cannot hold a job, have no lasting relationships and move aimlessly from place to place in an isolated orbit - and no one cares. The reason: They are extremely rich. The negative stereotypes of the children of the wealthy are many: self-indulgent, spoiled brats, ''poor little rich girls.'' All bespeak entrenched prejudices that rob the wealthy of sympathy for their psychological plaints. Wealth and its common companions, fame and power, are no insurance against life's pains, as the recent death of David Kennedy attests.
